lcInstruction.p: Metadata, or data about data, allows you to define information about your map and the topic references it contains. It adds semantic value to your map and can help facilitate filtering and search for both content creators and end users. Metadata is typically not shown in the final published output, but it can influence the way that your content is published—for example, by specifying how an output transform should generate cover information.

Including metadata in your map can be immensely helpful when it's time to publish and distribute your content. Metadata that's applied at the map level makes it easier for a tech pubs team to keep track of which maps they're responsible for updating and reviewing—or, depending on what kind of content management solution they're using, helps automate their content development workflow. It also allows helps give end users better results when they search for the published documents they need.

Metadata that's applied to individual topic or map references increases the map's semantic value even further. For example, if some of the topics in a map should only be published in electronic outputs, metadata applied to those topic references can tell the output transforms to filter out those topics during print publication. You can also use metadata to add semantic value to each topic or map reference within a map. One of the most useful examples of this is by adding a navigation title, which overrides the title of a topic with a different title that may be more appropriate for use in a table of contents or website navigation.

You can use metadata at the topic reference level to override metadata that already exists in the referenced topic. For example, if a referenced topic contains a <prolog> or <shortdesc> element, the metadata you add for that topic reference in your map will take precedence. You can also override metadata in a referenced map using the same method.

You can add metadata to a DITA map using the <topicmeta> element. The <topicmeta> element can exist at the main map level (inside the <map> element) or inside any <topicref> or <mapref> element within the map.

The structure of a <topicmeta> element might look something like this:

note.p: This lesson covers basic use of the <mapref> element and the elements it contains. For the full specifications for each element, see the OASIS DITA Version 1.2 Standard.

step.cmd: Inside the <map> element, after the <title> element, add a <topicmeta> element and add content to it as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE map PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Map//EN" "map.dtd"> <map id="ducks"> <title>Ducks</title> <topicmeta></topicmeta> </map>
